last_post.content:
A long toot for this #FollowFriday, my first one on this instance.

I find that #Mastodon’s coverage is surprisingly good on a number of topics. With more people joining by the day, it is getting better very rapidly.

I would like to mention a few here:
- #photography, especially #naturephotography
- #astronomy and #astrophysics
- #climatechange and #sustainability
- #Ukraine and the #war with #Russia

I’m happy to recommend specific accounts here. I would suggest, if you are interested in any of those #subjects, that you first run #followgraph on my main handle (fog@newsie.social), to identify the relevant ones.

If you don’t know followgraph, have a look at this fantastic tool, which was created by @gabipurcaru to enhance #discoverability: https://followgraph.vercel.app/

There are others areas, for which I need to spend more time to identify interesting accounts.

-#architecture, particularly #modernism and #contemporary #architects.
@concretelibraries is great. Do you have others you like?

- #arts, notably #finearts, #museums and current #exhibitions. There is @NationalGallery. A number of famous painters have their own bot, broadcasting images of their work, often without context. Who else would you recommend?

- #cinema: I have a couple of good handles on the history of the 7th art: @Cinematologists, @cinemaetpol (in French), @MoviesSilently. I could use more, notably on #currentmovies, #directors and #actors.

-#jazz #music
I’ve recently discovered a few good handles for #classicalmusic. I would love suggestions for jazz and #blues.

#FF

I am quite fed up with current state "AI" being hyped. It's so pathetic and has nothing to do with intelligence. That's just a clever marketing term, and it seems to be working :flan_sad:

Latest example is Google's MusicLM. It can create something like music from text prompts. Which is a cool feat, yes. But listen to the examples. They are so bad! Yes, you can hear what genre it's supposed do be. Yes, it's... Close to music. But it has nothing. No soul. No meaning. Not even words or melodies (!) that carry sense. It's tough to listen to more than a few seconds.

It's just probability, put to use.

It's "oh, after a sound that goes like this there's often a sound that goes like that in genre X." And frankly, for someone who loves to create and listen to music, these "songs" are close to torture in the way they defy everything I love about music.

You can find the "AI" here: https://google-research.github.io/seanet/musiclm/examples/

title: Petition: Do not remove LGBT content from the Relationships Education curriculum

last_post.content:
Regretfully, the petition to remove #LGBT content from the uk curriculum now has 194,723 signatures.

The counter petition asking for that content to remain, is rapidly gaining ground. It now has 57,963 signatures!

Pls sign the counter petition if able. British citizens/UK residents have the *right* to sign. Pls boost otherwise!👇

Link to official petition to UK Gov & Parliament: Do not remove LGBT content from the Relationships Education curriculum

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/631529

#LGBTQ #TransRights

I have become anecdotally aware of several (smaller) mastodon instances that are considering shutting down because they cannot afford their server bills.

If you are a #mastodonadmin of an instance that is 1000+ users and considering shutting down please reach out to me.

We may be willing to take over your instance and save your users if you are compliant with the Mastodon Server Covenenant (https://joinmastodon.org/covenant)

title: Google Changes Appeals Process for Suspected Child Abuse Images

last_post.content: After I did the story about the dad whose Google account was closed and deleted for taking a photo of his naked toddler for the doctor, I heard from a distraught mother in Colorado who was going through the same thing and didn't know why. Her Google account was disabled, taking with it her wedding photos, videos of her 9yo son growing up, tax documents, email and everything else. And she had no idea why. She was in tears. "It feels like my house burned down," she told me: https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/30/technology/google-appeals-change.html

title: LIVE Snow Cam @ Hyland Hills - Bloomington, Minnesota

last_post.content: sometimes I turn on this random Minnesota ski hill webcam and it is absolutely mesmerizing. Teens just blasting off jumps and rails (sometimes landing, sometimes crashing) and then everyone hits the rope tow with such aplomb. Seriously, just watch for a minute to see how 100 people who know what they are doing grab a ride on a rope tow, a normally unforgiving crappy kind of ski lift https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9USNTc7Gr4c

I can't believe today's #XKCD didn't already exist.

https://xkcd.com/2730/

title: Inside Japan’s long experiment in automating elder care

last_post.content:
After many years of research and much money spent, #robots for elder care seem like a failure in Japan.
“In short, the machines failed to save labor. The care robots themselves required care: they had to be moved around, maintained, cleaned, booted up, operated […]
Instead of saving time for staff to do more of the human labor of social and emotional care, the robots actually reduced the scope for such work.“
https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/01/09/1065135/japan-automating-eldercare-robots/

I really like this paper: Talking About Large Language Models, by Murray Shanahan

https://www.arxiv-vanity.com/papers/2212.03551/

> A bare-bones LLM doesn’t “really” know anything because all it does, at a fundamental level, is sequence prediction. Sometimes a predicted sequence takes the form of a proposition. But the special relationship propositional sequences have to truth is apparent only to the humans who are asking questions, or to those who provided the data the model was trained on.

Here are the lighthouses of Europe.

The map is even better than it might seem at first glance: the colors are the real colors, the patterns are the real patterns, and the size of the dots is the distance at which each light is visible.

Made with @openstreetmap, Leaflet, and the Overpass API.

https://geodienst.github.io/lighthousemap/

From the Geodienst researchers of Groningen University (NL), via Ethan Mollick

#lighthouse #geojson #openstreetmap #map

title: blog.pmarca.com: Report from the front: Tonight's launch of Open Social

last_post.content: I've spent the last few months bringing my 23+ years of blog archives up to date and modernizing them, while fixing the links and missing images, etc. Tonight's fun discovery is Marc Andreessen affirmatively citing my work as "the smartest thing anyone has said" about the inevitability of a federation of independent networks connected by an open standard to win against Facebook and similar walled gardens. Six months later in June 2008, he joined Facebook's board. https://web.archive.org/web/20080229063659/http://blog.pmarca.com/2007/11/report-from-the.html

title: Characterizing the Google Books Corpus: Strong Limits to Inferences of Socio-Cultural and Linguistic Evolution

last_post.content: Arguments that draw broad cultural inferences from the frequency of words in Google Books should be approached with considerable skepticism — new article in PLOS One. [Ed note: actually this was 2015!] (The article notes that genre-stabilized subsets like English Fiction are less subject to distortion.) https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0137041#pone-0137041-g013

title: ‘The Terraformers’ is a dazzling look at the distant future

last_post.content:
A review of The Terraformers in @WashingtonPost! "The reader of Annalee Newitz’s third novel, “The Terraformers,” will surely walk away, stunned and bedazzled…this generously overstuffed tale has enough ideas and incidents to populate half a dozen lesser science fiction books. But the reading experience is never clotted or tedious, never plagued by extraneous detours…[Newitz has] gifted us a vibrant, quirky vision of endless potential earned by heroism, love and wit."

https://www.washingtonpost.com/books/2023/01/27/annalee-newitz-terraformers/

@vicki You asked about the difference between search and recsys. Here is a great answer IMHO:
"an AI-driven search tool—that is, a tool that won't show you what you ask for, but rather, what it thinks you should see." from https://www.wired.com/story/tiktok-platforms-cory-doctorow/

With search you drive, with recsys you are driven.

title: Increasing ventilation reduces SARS-CoV-2 airborne transmission in schools: A retrospective cohort study in Italy's Marche region

last_post.content: Would improving ventilation actually help in schools? A study in Italy actually looked at more than 10,000 classrooms and found classrooms equipped with mechanical ventilation systems decreased the relative risk of COVID infection by at least 74% compared to classrooms with only natural ventilation ( https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpubh.2022.1087087/full ). H/T: @linseymarr 15/

@anildash The OpenSocial launch that night showed off the Friends, Profiles and Activities API model - here's a draft of my 2007 presentation about it https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1YEcl6gdJ5_GUstull98GYqKAjXZ2RhBf_AGw7iW7gTE/edit?usp=sharing

The Activities API there, which I helped design, became Activity Streams, went through a series of version and format transformations, and is now the basis of ActivityPub and how you're reading this now.

Sometimes the open journey is quite long.
